nodes.text: The widespread use of constant elasticity of substitution (CES) functions in integrated assessment models (IAMs) misrepresents long-term technical energy transitions and produces the artifact of monotonically and exponentially increasing carbon prices, undermining policy relevance

Integrated assessment models (IAMs) are core tools linking economic output, greenhouse gas emissions, climate impacts, and optimal carbon prices over decadal to century timeframes and consistently report increasing carbon prices

Applying CES functions to model substitution between technical energy inputs (e.g., fossil fuels and renewables) is conceptually inappropriate because CES is share-preserving and implies decreasing marginal rate of technical substitution that forces exponentially increasing replacement quantities and prices

Method demonstration: derive CES production, marginal rate of technical substitution (MRTS), and the relationship between relative prices and quantities for fossil (F) and renewable (R) energy and calculate carbon tax required to induce substitution under a competitive two-good model

Result of the stylized CES example: for realistic initial fossil shares and positive rho, the model requires exponentially increasing R to replace F, yields exponentially rising carbon taxes (even for partial substitution), and is highly sensitive to elasticity and initial shares

Evidence from multiple mainstream IAMs (GTEM-C, EPPA, GCAM, MERGE, hybrid models) shows nested CES structures and produces carbon price trajectories that rise steeply and favor incumbent technologies like CCS, nuclear, or biomass with CCS

CES cannot reproduce historically observed S-curve technological diffusion because real technological substitution exhibits dynamically changing elasticity of substitution (becoming easier as penetration increases)

Empirical evidence: historical energy transitions and broad technology diffusion studies exhibit S-curve or logistic/Gompertz/Bass diffusion patterns and concurrent exponential deployment and cost declines (e.g., Nagy et al., Grubler, Fouquet, Marchetti)

Relying on CES-driven IAM outputs causes three policy harms: price diversion (overemphasis on price instruments over physical planning), sticker shock (perceived impossibility due to huge predicted carbon prices), and technological myopia (favoring incumbent technologies present in initial model shares)

Observed implication: IAMs using CES produce very high carbon price estimates that create perception of high mitigation cost, discourage ambitious deployment policy, and bias outcomes toward technologies already represented in model shares

Methodological proposal: modify IAM formulations by using dynamically varying elasticity of substitution (linearly or exponentially changing rho) calibrated to expected technical evolution to better replicate S-curve transitions

Result of dynamic-elasticity experiments: dynamically decreasing elasticity produces substitution trajectories more consistent with S-curve diffusion and avoids the artifact of exponentially rising carbon prices

Conclusion: IAMs need a paradigm shift toward approaches that reflect physical energy principles and dynamic substitution (including deployment targets and system-level physical planning), because CES-based economic formulations produce misleading carbon price signals and poor guidance for energy policy

Limitation and broader criticisms: independent of CES misuse, IAMs face major external shortcomings including sensitive discount rate choices, simplistic or biased climate damage functions, underestimation of fat-tail catastrophic risks, and the use of GDP as a proxy for welfare

Evidence on those broader issues: damage functions often understate high-warming impacts and ignore interactions and fat tails, discount rate selection dramatically affects outcomes, and monetization approaches produce ethically and methodologically problematic valuations

Recommendation: complement or replace CES-based IAM elements with physics-driven energy models, explicit deployment and storage planning, and assessment of combined levelized costs (RE plus storage), rather than relying solely on price signals
